tg.trunc: get in peoples' way.
of its own accord. Of one's own will.
by itself, of own accord; move ahead of own accord; willingly
one's own. Immediate. E.g. family. one's own, personal
new Year's Day.
an outer cloth covering for a baby's head. A baby's veil, for a moss bag.
a bee's nest, [Bee hive].
the sense of sight. 2. One's status.
flowers or a decoration on one's lapel.
defence of one's children.
watching one's behaviour.
april Fool's Day.
paying for one's own wrongdoing.
a driver's license.
supporting one's self.
losing one's way.
the act of taking land as one's own land living on it.
a dog's panting from the heat.
the chief's daughter.
chief's daughter; daughter of anyone known as "okimâw"; princess
the chief's wife.
queen; female boss, female of high position; chief's wife, wife of anyone known as "okimâw"

my first cousin. Father's brother's son or mother's sister's son. 1. my male parallel cousin; husband of my female cross-cousin; [used by male speaker only] 2. my brother; my friend; my fellow age-mate male 3. [plural:] brethren [in Christian sense] 4. my rival
my aunt [my father's sister]. Also, my mother-in-law. my aunt, my cross-aunt; my father's sister, my mother's brother's wife; my mother-in-law
my uncle [My mother's brother]. Also my father-in-law. my uncle, my cross-uncle; my mother's brother, my father's sister's husband; my father-in-law

my nephew, my sister's son [from a male point of view] or my brother's son [from a female point of view]. 1. my nephew, my cross-nephew [i.e. son of sibling of opposite gender]; my son-in-law 2. [male speaker:] my sister's son 3. [female speaker:] my brother's son

my first cousin. Father's brother's daughter or mother's sister's daughter. 1. my female parallel cousin; wife of my male cross-cousin; my father's brother's daughter, my mother's sister's daughter 2. my fellow tribeswoman 3. my sister-in-law
a bee's stinger. Also a small pin. This term is also sometimes used for a fork. fork; small awl
target, bull's-eye
a small bear's hill located in Hobbema. Hobbema, AB; literally: "Little Bear Hills"
expense. One's spending.
expense, spending; waste
the digestive organ of a cow's stomach. "bible", manyplies, omasum, third stomach of ruminant, digestive organ of a moose or cow's stomach
be shaded by another person's shadow.
braid someone's hair.
the wind is knocked out of him by another's movement.
anything that is pointed [or conical] in shape. E.g.. A steep hill. From the observer's point of view, mean it is in an upright position.
be used for another's own convenience. That is how he is used.
let's go.
his mouth is kept shut by someone's hands.
his neck is broken by hand. As a duck's neck.
1. His pain is made worse by somebody's hands. Also in movement.
1. be made to sound [as a car or horm]. 2. imitate him in his cry [as a n animal's].
imitate his cry [an animal's].
the wind's direction has changed. There is a change in the direction of the wind. E.g. From West to East.
quickly moves into another's spot.
be in three's. By three's.
be carried on somebody's back.
go with him [Also includes agreement with a another's idea].
go to a door but the door is locked or nobody's home.
slip out of someone's hands.
keep up with it. E.g.. The job's pace.
complain about details of another's actions to him.
break his neck [as a chicken's neck].
break s.o.'s neck by hand, ring s.o.'s neck
hold his/her own hands over s.o.'s eyes
dislocate someone else's joint.
dislocate s.o., cripple s.o.
take [it/him] out of s.o.'s mouth
break his neck by hand. As a chicken's neck.
ring s.o.'s neck; break s.o.'s neck off [by hand]
chew s.o. [e.g. tobacco]
cut the head off at the neck. E.g.. As a chicken's or other fowl.
cut s.o.'s throat, sever s.o.'s neck, cut off s.o.'s head [by cutting edge]
come, let's see
let me pass, please.
well, then, please; come, let's see [hortatory]
please; let's see
all right, let's go
okay; ready, let's go
now then; ready, all right, let's go, come on; well; [hortatory, indicating readiness or impatience]
all right, fine, let's go
o.k. now, let's go
let's sit where it is warm.
bellow long and loud [* Note, legendary Cree word not usually used].
one million, 1,000,000; literally: "an extreme-great-hundred; an extreme thousand"
thousand, one thousand
be midnight [12:00 a.m.]
at noon, when it's noon [12:00 p.m.]
be noon [12:00 p.m.]
and a quarter [of an hour], 15 minutes or so
The Riel Resistance of 1885; literally: "when it went wrong; when bad things happened"

1. All the time. keep happening.
only, exclusively; it is only that; instead of

always, constantly, all the time, repeated action

here, here it is, take it [deictic; used when giving or handing an object to someone]

1. carpenter; literally: "wood-man" 2. John Smith, chief of Muskoday First Nation, signatory to Treaty 6
Big Bear; prominent Cree chief, signatory to an adhesion to Treaty 6; wrongfully persecuted and imprisoned in the backlash to the Riel Resistance
